text: I really think a lot of people become irrational when it comes to PC. Minimising PC is not a desirable end in itself, what's desirable is maximising your income. You know what's worse than paying PC? NOT paying PC. Whatever your situation the prescription is the same: Maximise your betting profits. If you have a high variability strategy that generates a lot of comm that's fine, but you'll still take more money home if you can reduce that variability. Variability is losing, losing isn't winning, it's that simple.

elements.text: I really think a lot of people become irrational when it comes to PC. Minimising PC is not a desirable end in itself, what's desirable is maximising your income. If you have a high variability strategy that generates a lot of comm that's fine, but you'll still take more money home if you can reduce that variability. Variability is losing, losing isn't winning, it's that simple.

text: I think here the basic criteria of what constitutes a business is that you have customers. This was tested with reference to BF some years ago and it was found that your counter-parties aren't counted as customers, your bets are struck against BF and the fact that they hedge out their bet with a counter bet is their business not yours.

elements.text: I think here the basic criteria of what constitutes a business is that you have customers. This was tested with reference to BF some years ago and it was found that your counter-parties aren't counted as customers, your bets are struck against BF and the fact that they hedge out their bet with a counter bet is their business not yours.

text: <@U017NPYRVHR> has joined the channel

Hi all, thanks for letting me join the group :) I want to get into betting and I'm wondering if there are any resources (e.g. books, blogs, etc.) that you guys can recommend? I'm an "expert" in algorithms, software development, machine learning and probability theory but I know very little about the world of betting (and also very little about trading) - I'm only saying that to say that I'm not too interested in general programming books and so on :)

Another related newbie question: I'm especially interested in football (soccer) betting. My guess is that my biggest chance for betting profitably there would be through live betting (I want to bet 100% programmatically). Are there any live feed sources that you can recommend? I have saved up around 30k euro that I plan to risk on getting started - is that enough, or do you need a higher volume to avoid all of your winnings going to paying monthly live feed APIs? (I can see from the slack history that some of you guys are winning considerably more than that)

elements.text:

text: 30k is 29.5k  too much. No additional data needed. There are no books that will tell you anything that you couldn't read here for free.

elements.text: 30k is 29.5k  too much. No additional data needed. There are no books that will tell you anything that you couldn't read here for free.

text: Newbie question - I'm assuming basic market strategies like any inter market arbs or dutching whole field when book < 100% is pretty much non existent these days?

elements.text: Newbie question - I'm assuming basic market strategies like any inter market arbs or dutching whole field when book < 100% is pretty much non existent these days?

text: <@U016NCFUSH1> you will need to decide what you want to bet on specifically. Are you betting on the outcome of an event, or are you betting on price changes? Once you decide exactly what you want to forecast, then you can figure out what data you want to collect. I agree also that the discussions in this group are enough to get you going.

elements.text: you will need to decide what you want to bet on specifically. Are you betting on the outcome of an event, or are you betting on price changes? Once you decide exactly what you want to forecast, then you can figure out what data you want to collect. I agree also that the discussions in this group are enough to get you going.

text:
There are academic papers worth reading to give you ideas for how to model specific sports. For example, <https://tolstoy.newcastle.edu.au/R/e8/help/att-6544/dixoncoles97.pdf|Dixon and Coles> is the seminal paper for modelling football pre-event and <https://wwwf.imperial.ac.uk/~ejm/M3S4/Problems/football.pdf|Dixon and Robinson> extends the idea to in-running.

For tennis, a good but increasingly dated starting point is <http://www.strategicgames.com.au/PhD.pdf|Tristan Barnett's PhD thesis>. The various papers coming out of <https://www.imperial.ac.uk/people/w.knottenbelt/publications.html|Will Knottenbelt>'s group at Imperial College are more recent additions.

But thinking about how to take these models and build automated trading platforms that utilise them is a whole other ball game. There aren't really any books out there to recommend. Personally, I think you are already utilising the best available resource by being part of this Slack channel.

text: Wow. Cool. That surprises me quite a bit :) Are you saying that no additional data is needed because it's possible to win small amounts without additional data or because you don't think that additional data is worth much to a strategy?

elements.text: Wow. Cool. That surprises me quite a bit :) Are you saying that no additional data is needed because it's possible to win small amounts without additional data or because you don't think that additional data is worth much to a strategy?

text: I think there are 2 basic approaches: You can do the <@UBS7QANF3> approach where you use a tonne of resources, several people and a very high level of expertise and that can work (although it's high risk) - but 30k is nothing like enough for that. On the other hand you can start small, keep your costs down and build up organically. That also works and it's very low risk but slow. I don't think there's a middle route.

elements.text: I think there are 2 basic approaches: You can do the

approach where you use a tonne of resources, several people and a very high level of expertise and that can work (although it's high risk) - but 30k is nothing like enough for that. On the other hand you can start small, keep your costs down and build up organically. That also works and it's very low risk but slow. I don't think there's a middle route.

text: Ok, that makes sense. I guess it is not necessarily impossible to find some kind of middle ground, but I will probably find out :)

elements.text: Ok, that makes sense. I guess it is not necessarily impossible to find some kind of middle ground, but I will probably find out :)

text: Sure it's probably possible - but remember that successful gamblers out outliers, I wouldn't count on being an outlier amongst the outliers.

elements.text: Sure it's probably possible - but remember that successful gamblers out outliers, I wouldn't count on being an outlier amongst the outliers.

text: That's a great point, which I haven't given a lot of thought. I guess I have mostly been thinking that I'd want to make bets that are profitable in expectation.

elements.text: That's a great point, which I haven't given a lot of thought. I guess I have mostly been thinking that I'd want to make bets that are profitable in expectation.

text: <@UBS7QANF3> So basically don't rule anything out until it's tried, backtested, and put through it's paces...
